title: Taxi driver praised by police for saving victim of sex trafficking
text:
The National Crime Agency combats organised crime in the UK, principally human trafficking, modern slavery, weapons and drugs crime and child exploitation. - Getty Images

A cab driver has been hailed by police after he saved a woman trafficked into the UK to be prostituted.

Tahir Mehmood, a Coventry-based taxi driver, is in line for a police commendation after saving the victim from being forced into the sex trade.

Police rescued the Romanian woman on February 20 last year after being alerted by Mr Mehmood that the woman was being coerced.

The next day officers raided a brothel in the city to rescue several other suspected sex slaves.

Mr Mehmood had been called by Robert Enescu, 26, who wanted the woman to be ferried to a location across the city. During the ride Mr Mehmood's passenger, a married woman that had arrived in the UK four days previously, broke down and revealed she had been lured to the UK on the false promise of a masseuse job and subsequently forced into illegal sex work.

Mr Mehmood, a married father of two, immediately called the police.

Enescu was later arrested and jailed for nine years in his absence having jumped bail. West Midlands Police is working with forces across the UK and Europol to bring him to justice.

Mr Mehmood said the woman started crying when left alone in his taxi. “I said ‘what's up love? Why are you crying?’ I stopped the taxi and said ‘just tell me what's happened,’” he told Mail Online.

“She said ‘I don't know here, I just came here four days before, come to here to do massage, but they tell me go to prostitution, to do sex, but I don't want to do it. Can you help me go back to my country? The man said I got to do prostitution sex but I don't want to do it.’”

Detective Inspector Wes Martin of West Midlands Police's Public Protection Unit, praised Mr Mehmood, a taxi driver since 2004, for noticing some of the potential signs of human trafficking, such as a panicked or stressful passenger with a lack of belongings.

Det Insp Martin said: “The taxi driver is going to be referred for a commendation because what a fantastic member of the public he was to do what he did.

“He's a family man, a local Asian taxi driver, and it was a very honourable thing he did.”

Coventry councillor Naeem Akhtar said: “The council provides training and information to licensed taxi drivers that if they see something suspicious and believe something is wrong then they must contact the relevant agency.

“This driver could have just ignored what he saw and the victim would have ended up in a brothel. Mr Mehmood's actions saved her.”

The National Crime Agency (NCA) says that 136 potential victims of human trafficking were rescued as a result of the agency’s activity in 2017 to 2018.

It says most victims of modern slavery and human trafficking are ‘recruited’ in person, although some who find themselves trapped in the sex industry have been ensnared through online job adverts and social media websites.

A series of adverts titled ‘Can you see me?’ highlight how many people working in the construction, agriculture or sex industries and in places like nail bars and car washes have been trafficked and suggests ways the public could help identify victims.
description: A cab driver has been hailed by police after he saved a woman trafficked into the UK to be prostituted.
